questions.text: A man suffered from road traffic accident that lead to trauma to the spinal cord. On investigation, a complete transection of one side of the spinal cord is suspected. For below the level of injury Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding this case?
questions.solution:
• Contralateral loss of pain and temperature occurs because the spinothalamic tract crosses to the opposite side at the spinal cord level. This means damage on one side results in loss of these sensations on the opposite side of the body, below the lesion.
  • Corticosteroids are effective in reducing inflammation if administered early, as they suppress immune cells and reduce capillary permeability, preventing further damage from swelling and inflammation.
  • Ipsilateral loss of fine touch, vibration, and proprioception occurs due to damage to the fasciculus gracilis or fasciculus cuneatus (dorsal column), which ascends without crossing until it reaches the medulla. This leads to loss of stereognosis on the same side of the lesion.
  • Ipsilateral weakness and spasticity arise from damage to the corticospinal tract (a motor pathway) that affects the same side of the body. Since corticospinal fibers cross at the medulla, any damage below this level affects motor control ipsilaterally.

Why not others:

  • Contralateral pain and temperature loss happens due to spinothalamic tract involvement.
  • Corticosteroids prevent secondary damage from inflammation and swelling.
  • Ipsilateral stereognosis loss is due to the dorsal column damage, and ipsilateral motor weakness is caused by corticospinal tract disruption.

Key Takeaways:

  • Spinal cord hemisection results in contralateral loss of pain/temperature and ipsilateral loss of fine touch, proprioception, and motor control.
  • Early corticosteroid therapy can reduce secondary damage in spinal cord injuries.

choices.text: Reduced incidence of phantom pain following epidural anaesthesia during surgery is reported
Lateral dorsal thalamic nucleus is one example where this change can occur
Spinal cord stimulation has been shown to be effective therapy for phantom pain

questions.text: A military after amputation tells the doctor that he still feels the pain in the amputated part. Which is incorrect statement regarding this case?
questions.solution:
• Reduced incidence of phantom pain has been reported after epidural anesthesia during amputation surgery, as it may prevent acute surgical pain.
  • Phantom pain is based on cortical plasticity, where adjacent areas take over the cortical representation of the amputated limb.
  • The ventral posterior thalamic nucleus, not the lateral dorsal thalamic nucleus, is one example where cortical changes can occur.
  • Spinal cord stimulation has been shown to effectively reduce phantom pain. Electric current passed next to spinal cord interferes with the impulses ascending to the brain and lessens the pain felt in the phantom limb.

Why Not Others

  • A: Correct, as evidence supports the reduction of phantom pain with epidural anesthesia.
  • B: Correct, phantom pain is associated with cortical plasticity.
  • C: Incorrect, the ventral posterior thalamic nucleus is involved, not the lateral dorsal.
  • D: Correct, spinal cord stimulation is an effective therapy for phantom pain.

Key Takeaways

  • Phantom pain is due to cortical plasticity and can be managed with spinal cord stimulation.
  • The ventral posterior thalamic nucleus is involved in phantom pain, not the lateral dorsal nucleus.

questions.text: Which of the following sensation will be intact if there is any injury to the tract given below
questions.solution:
• The dorsal column pathway mediates fine touch, vibration, conscious proprioception, and stereognosis.
  • Sensory fibers ascend ipsilaterally in the spinal dorsal columns and cross at the medulla to reach the thalamic ventral posterior lateral nucleus and primary somatosensory cortex.
  • Pain sensation is carried by the spinothalamic tract, not the dorsal column, so it remains intact if the dorsal column is injured.

Why Not Others

  • B: Incorrect, conscious proprioception is mediated by the dorsal column and would be affected.
  • C: Incorrect, stereognosis (ability to recognize objects by touch) is mediated by the dorsal column and would be affected.
  • D: Incorrect, fine touch is mediated by the dorsal column and would be impaired.

Key Takeaways

  • Pain sensation remains intact with dorsal column injury, as it's mediated by the spinothalamic tract.
  • Dorsal column injury affects fine touch, vibration, conscious proprioception, and stereognosis.

choices.text: Sensory homunculus is a topographical representations of distribution of sensory input to the somatosensory cortex from different parts of body
Somatosensory area has the largest representation for legs
The size of the cortical receiving area for impulses from a particular part of the body is proportionate to the use of the part
Medial portion of postcentral gyrus received information from trunk

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement regarding the given picture.
questions.solution:
• The sensory homunculus is a topographical representation of sensory input distribution to the somatosensory cortex from different body parts.
  • The size of the cortical area corresponds to the functional importance and number of sensory receptors, not the area of the body.
  • In the sensory homunculus, the legs do not have the largest representation; the face and hands have a larger representation compared to the legs and trunk.

Other options-

  • Option A: Correct, the sensory homunculus indeed represents the distribution of sensory input to the somatosensory cortex.
  • Option C: Correct, the size of the cortical area is proportional to the use and sensitivity of that body part.
  • Option D: Correct, the medial portion of the postcentral gyrus receives sensory information from the trunk and lower extremities.

Key Takeaways

  • Incorrect statement: The somatosensory area does not have the largest representation for the legs; it is primarily for the face and hands.
  • The sensory homunculus reflects functional importance rather than body size, with the cortex dedicated to body parts based on sensory input.

questions.text: During Olympics, an athlete sprain an ankle but continued playing without feeling immediate pain. This is an example of stress-induced analgesia. This occurs due to release of?
questions.solution:
• Stress-induced analgesia is a phenomenon where an individual experiences a reduction in pain perception during stressful situations, such as sports injuries.
  • This analgesia is primarily attributed to the release of norepinephrine from brainstem and amygdala and endogenous cannabinoids (like 2-arachidonoylglycerol and anandamide), activating via CB2 receptors which modulate pain pathways in the brain and spinal cord.

Why Not Others

  • B (Substance P): Incorrect, as Substance P is a neuropeptide associated with pain transmission, not analgesia.
  • C (Cortisol): Incorrect, while cortisol is a stress hormone that can affect pain perception, it is not directly responsible for inducing analgesia.
  • D (Serotonin): Incorrect, although serotonin can influence mood and pain perception, it is not primarily linked to stress-induced analgesia.

Key Takeaways

  • Correct answer: Stress-induced analgesia occurs due to the release of cannabinoids and norepinephrine.
  • This mechanism illustrates how the body can naturally inhibit pain in response to stressful conditions, allowing individuals to perform despite injuries.

questions.text: Identify the following tract whether it is ascending or descending and which of the following sensation does it carries from the given option?
questions.solution:
• The ventrolateral spinothalamic tract is an ascending pathway responsible for transmitting pain, temperature, crude touch, pressure, and itch
  • Sensory fibers from this tract terminate in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord, where they cross to the opposite side and ascend to the ventral posterolateral (VPL) nucleus of the thalamus, eventually projecting to the primary somatosensory cortex.

Why Not Others

  • A (Ascending pathway carrying vibration sensation): Incorrect, as vibration sensation is primarily carried by the dorsal column-medial lemniscal pathway, not the spinothalamic tract.
  • B (Descending pathway controlling voluntary movements): Incorrect, since the spinothalamic tract is not a descending pathway; descending pathways include the corticospinal tract.
  • D (Ascending pathway carrying conscious proprioception): Incorrect, as conscious proprioception is also primarily carried by the dorsal column-medial lemniscal pathway.

Key Takeaways

  • Correct answer: The ventrolateral spinothalamic tract is an ascending pathway that carries itch
  • This pathway plays a critical role in transmitting nociceptive signals and other non-specific sensations to the brain for interpretation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman was rushed to the emergency department after getting stabbed with a sharp weapon. On MRI, complete transection of one side of spinal cord is suspected. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Brown-Sequard Syndrome results from hemisection of the spinal cord, causing:

  • Ipsilateral Loss of Proprioception: Due to damage to dorsal columns.
  • Contralateral Loss of Pain and Temperature: Due to damage to the spinothalamic tract.
  • Ipsilateral Flaccid Paralysis: At the level of the lesion due to lower motor neuron damage.
  • Contralateral Spastic Paralysis: Below the level of the lesion due to upper motor neuron damage.

Why not other options:

Option A: Ipsilateral loss of proprioception: This is expected in Brown-Sequard syndrome due to damage to the dorsal columns on the same side as the lesion.

Option B: Contralateral loss of pain: This occurs because the spinothalamic tract, responsible for pain and temperature sensation, crosses over to the opposite side before ascending.

Option D: Contralateral loss of temperature: Similar to pain, the loss of temperature sensation occurs contralaterally due to the crossing of the spinothalamic tract.

Key Takeaways: In a patient with suspected complete transection of one side of the spinal cord, the least likely finding would be contralateral flaccid and spastic paralysis, as paralysis is typically ipsilateral due to damage to the corticospinal tract on the same side as the injury (Brown-Sequard syndrome).

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the nature of the sensory receptor given in image below.
questions.solution:
• The sensory receptor shown is the Pacinian corpuscle, which is specialized for detecting vibrations and deep pressure.
  • Fast Adapting: It is a rapidly adapting mechanoreceptor, meaning it responds swiftly when a stimulus is applied but stops firing if the stimulus continues. This allows it to detect changes in pressure and vibrations rather than constant pressure.
  • Encapsulated: The receptor is encapsulated within layers of connective tissue (lamellae), which helps in filtering the type of mechanical stimuli it responds to, making it highly sensitive to rapid changes.
  • These receptors are commonly found in locations like the skin, joints, and deeper tissues.

Why Not Other Options

  • A: Merkel discs are slow-adapting, meaning they continuously respond to sustained stimuli, and are not encapsulated. These cells detect light touch and texture and are found in the basal layer of the epidermis

B: A receptor that is slow adapting and encapsulated could theoretically be designed to sustain pressure over time, but this is not a typical feature for most known receptors.

D: Receptors that are fast-adapting stop firing action potentials quickly when exposed to a sustained stimulus, meaning they respond mainly to changes in the stimulus. These receptors are usually encapsulated. This option is not true.

Key Takeaways

  • Pacinian corpuscles are encapsulated, fast-adapting receptors that detect vibrations and deep pressure.
  • They are crucial for sensing rapid changes in the environment, not sustained pressure.

questions.text: A patient who recently had a leg amputation reports feeling pain in the missing limb, a phenomenon known as phantom limb pain. This phenomenon is based on which of the following mechanism.
questions.solution:
• Phantom limb pain arises due to cortical plasticity, which refers to the brain's ability to reorganize itself after injury or amputation.
  • After the loss of a limb, the cortical representation of that limb is taken over by adjacent areas in the brain. This can lead to misinterpretation of signals, resulting in sensations like pain, itching, or tingling in the missing limb.
  • Rewiring of neural circuits occurs, and neurons that were previously connected to the amputated limb now respond to stimuli from other parts of the body, but the brain may still perceive these signals as coming from the missing limb.
  • This process is an example of the brain's adaptability but can cause discomfort as the brain attempts to process signals without proper input from the absent limb.

Why Not Other Options

  • B (Weber French Law): Deals with the relationship between stimulus magnitude and perception, irrelevant to cortical reorganization.
  • C (Principle of Labeled Time): Involves temporal coding of sensory information, not applicable to phantom limb pain.
  • D (Muller's Specific Nerve Energy): Relates to how specific nerves produce distinct sensations, regardless of stimulus, which doesn't explain cortical reorganization.

Key Takeaways

  • Cortical plasticity leads to phantom limb pain, where the brain reorganizes and adjacent regions take over the area once representing the amputated limb.
  • This reorganization may cause sensory confusion, leading to the perception of pain or sensations in the missing limb.

choices.text: TENS directly stimulates the muscles, leading to relaxation and pain relief.
TENS works by blocking the transmission of pain signals to the brain through the activation of large sensory fibers that close the "pain gate"
TENS stimulates the release of endorphins, which are natural painkillers in the body
TENS alters the pain perception by modulating the central nervous system's response to pain.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old patient with chronic lower back pain is prescribed transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) as a part of their pain management plan. The patient experiences significant pain relief after the treatment.
What is the most likely mechanism by which TENS provides pain relief in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS) primarily provides pain relief through the gate control theory of pain.
  • Mechanism of Action: TENS stimulates large sensory fibers, which blocks the transmission of pain signals from smaller nociceptive fibers at the spinal cord level, effectively "closing the gate" and preventing pain signals from reaching the brain.
  • Pain Signal Inhibition: By activating these larger fibers, TENS reduces the perception of pain, as fewer signals are transmitted through the pain pathways.
  • Additional Effects: While TENS may also lead to the release of endorphins, the dominant mechanism in this scenario is the modulation of pain transmission via the spinal cord.

Why Not Other Options

  • A: While TENS involves electrical stimulation, it does not primarily provide relief through direct muscle stimulation; rather, it modulates nerve activity.
  • C: Endorphin release can contribute to pain relief, but it's not the primary mechanism of TENS; this effect is more prominent in methods like exercise or acupuncture.
  • D: Although TENS can influence pain perception, the gate control theory explains its action more accurately, focusing on spinal cord modulation rather than broader central nervous system effects.

Key Takeaways

  • TENS provides pain relief primarily by blocking pain signal transmission through the activation of large sensory fibers, following the gate control theory.
  • This mechanism is key to understanding how TENS effectively reduces pain in patients with chronic conditions like lower back pain.

choices.text: The brain misinterprets signals from the damaged neural pathways, leading to referred sensations in the hand.
The sensory pathways from the hand and cheek converge at a common relay in the spinal cord, causing cross-wiring of sensations
The brain projects the sensation to the location where it expects the stimulus to be, based on previous sensory experiences, despite the stimulus being applied elsewhere.
Neuroplastic changes in the brain after the surgery have resulted in the reorganization of sensory maps, leading to altered perception of touch

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman undergoes a complex neurosurgical procedure to remove a brain tumor. Post-operatively, she reports feeling a sensation of warmth in her left hand whenever her right cheek is touched, even though there is no direct stimulus applied to her hand.
What is the most likely explanation for the patient's unusual sensation of warmth in her left hand when her right cheek is touched?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon described is explained by the law of projection, where the brain perceives sensations as originating from their usual anatomical locations based on previous sensory experiences, even if the stimulus is applied elsewhere.

  • In this case, the brain projects the sensation to the left hand because it expects the stimulus to come from there, even though the stimulus is applied to the right cheek.
  • This occurs because the brain's sensory maps are hardwired to expect certain sensations from specific areas, and post-surgical changes can disrupt this perception.

Why Not Other Options

  • A: Misinterpreted signals due to damaged pathways usually refer to referred pain, not a projection of sensation based on previous sensory experiences.
  • B: While pathways can converge, this explanation lacks detail about the brain's role in interpreting and projecting sensory information.
  • D: Neuroplasticity explains long-term changes in sensory maps, but the immediate sensation described here is better explained by the law of projection.

Key Takeaways

  • The law of projection explains how the brain perceives sensations from areas based on previous experiences, leading to the perception of touch in one area despite the stimulus being elsewhere.
  • Post-surgical changes in neural pathways can result in altered perception of sensory inputs, as seen in this case.

questions.text: Imagine a researcher conducting an experiment to unlock the secrets of the human body's sensory capabilities. During their investigation, they apply a firm pressure to the skin and notice a certain receptor springing into action, responding eagerly to the distortion of the tissue. If you were to categorize this receptor based on its response to mechanical forces, what classification would you assign it?
questions.solution:
• The receptor that responds to firm pressure applied to the skin is classified as a mechanoreceptor.
  • Function: Mechanoreceptors are specialized for detecting mechanical stimuli, such as pressure, stretch, and vibration.
  • Examples: These include Pacinian corpuscles, which respond to deep pressure and vibration, and Meissner's corpuscles, which are sensitive to light touch.
    Baroreceptors are an example of mechanoreceptors
  • Mechanoreceptors play a crucial role in the body's ability to sense changes in the environment, providing important information about the physical state of the surroundings.

Why Not Other Options

  • A (Chemoreceptor): These receptors detect chemical changes (e.g., oxygen, pH) and are not responsive to mechanical forces.
    Example: Carotid and aortic bodies
  • B (Thermoreceptor): Sensitive to temperature changes (heat and cold), thermoreceptors do not react to pressure stimuli.
  • D (Nociceptor): Although they signal pain from harmful stimuli (including extreme pressure), nociceptors primarily indicate danger rather than detecting normal mechanical changes.
    Example: pain receptors

Key Takeaways

  • Mechanoreceptors are the receptors responsible for detecting mechanical forces like pressure, stretch, and vibration.

questions.text: During a physiology lecture, a professor describes a type of sensory receptor that quickly responds to a stimulus but then stops firing even if the stimulus continues. This receptor is crucial for detecting changes in the environment, such as the onset and offset of a stimulus. What is true regarding this receptor?
questions.solution:
• The sensory receptor described is a phasic receptor, which quickly responds to a stimulus but ceases firing even if the stimulus persists.
  • These receptors are rapidly adapting receptors
  • Function: Phasic receptors are essential for detecting changes in the environment, particularly the onset and offset of stimuli, rather than ongoing stimuli.
  • Examples:
    • Pacinian corpuscles: Detect deep pressure and vibrations.
    • Meissner's corpuscles: Sensitive to light touch and changes in texture.
  • These receptors are designed to provide information about dynamic changes rather than maintaining continuous awareness of a steady stimulus.

Why Not Other Options

  • A: Tonic receptors are slow adapting and continue to respond for the duration of the stimulus, opposite to phasic receptors.
  • B: Phasic receptors do not respond to steady stimuli; they respond to changes, making this statement incorrect.
  • C: Phasic receptors like Pacinian and Meissner corpuscles are encapsulated, while free nerve endings typically detect pain and temperature.

Key Takeaways

  • Phasic receptors, such as Pacinian and Meissner corpuscles, rapidly adapt and are crucial for detecting changes in stimuli.
